snippet: The company said about 14 percent of its work force would be eliminated, largely in the mobile phone business it acquired from Nokia.
abstract: Microsoft announces that it will lay off up to 18,000 employees, many of them from company's troubled Nokia phone business, in an attempt at reinvigoration; cuts would be largest in company's history, and are the first major change by new chief executive Satya Nadella; Microsoft, while still profitable, has been consistently left behind as newer companies like Google and Facebook define the next generation of technology.

byline.contributor: Mark Scott contributed reporting from London.

lead_paragraph: The company said about 14 percent of its work force would be eliminated, largely in the mobile phone business it acquired from Nokia.

headline.main: Microsoft to Lay Off Thousands, Most From Nokia Unit
